title: You could have a secret twin (but not the way you think) - Kayla Mandel Sheets

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the condition where an individual has two genomes present in the tissues of their body?

options.label: A
options.text: Mosaicism

options.label: B
options.text: Chimerism

options.label: C
options.text: Twinning

options.label: D
options.text: Genetic mutation

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the most common form of chimerism?

options.label: A
options.text: Tissue or organ transplant

options.label: B
options.text: Mother and fetus swapping cells in the flow of nutrients across the placenta

options.label: C
options.text: Fetal stem cells being inherited from a twin in utero

options.label: D
options.text: Genetic testing

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about Karen Keegan's condition, where she has a second genome in some tissues and organs?

options.label: A
options.text: She has two-toned skin or hair

options.label: B
options.text: She has two different colored eyes

options.label: C
options.text: She has cells with a completely different set of genes from the others

options.label: D
options.text: She has no visible signs of the condition

multiple-choice.question: How can chimerism occur between a fetus and a pregnant woman?

options.label: A
options.text: Through a tissue or organ transplant

options.label: B
options.text: Through the mother's immune system attacking the fetus's cells

options.label: C
options.text: Through the mother and fetus swapping cells in the flow of nutrients across the placenta

options.label: D
options.text: Through genetic testing

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what happened to Karen Keegan's fraternal twin?

options.label: A
options.text: The twin developed into a healthy baby

options.label: B
options.text: The twin did not develop to term

options.label: C
options.text: The twin was born with a genetic mutation

options.label: D
options.text: The twin was adopted by another family

multiple-choice.question: What is the process where an individual's immune system recognizes both genomes as their body's own?

options.label: A
options.text: Immune rejection

options.label: B
options.text: Immune tolerance

options.label: C
options.text: Genetic adaptation

options.label: D
options.text: Chimerism

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what percentage of a father's sperm can carry a second genome from an embryonic twin?
What is the significance of the fact that 1 in 8 individual births started out as twin pregnancies?

options.label: A
options.text: It means that 1 in 8 people have chimerism

options.label: B
options.text: It means that 1 in 8 people have a genetic mutation

options.label: C
options.text: It means that there could be many more people with two genomes

options.label: D
options.text: It means that there is no correlation between twin pregnancies and chimerism

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what can happen to a mother's body as a result of chimerism?

options.label: A
options.text: She may have two-toned skin or hair

options.label: B
options.text: She may have two different colored eyes

options.label: C
options.text: She may have cells with a completely different set of genes from her other cells

options.label: D
options.text: She may have no visible signs of the condition

multiple-choice.question: What is the broader implication of the fact that we're all amalgams to some extent, carrying around the different genetic codes of our gut bacteria and even our mitochondria?

options.label: A
options.text: It means that we are all genetically identical

options.label: B
options.text: It means that we are all genetically unique

options.label: C
options.text: It means that there is no correlation between genetic diversity and health

options.label: D
options.text: It means that we are all interconnected and interdependent

title: Earth's mysterious red glow, explained - Zoe Pierrat

multiple-choice.question: What phenomenon was observed by satellite in 2009, which couldn't have been caused by plants but couldn't have been reflected sunlight due to its unique wavelength?

options.label: A
options.text: Chlorophyll fluorescence

options.label: B
options.text: Photosynthesis

options.label: C
options.text: The Earth's red glow

options.label: D
options.text: The spectral signature of carbon dioxide

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is one of the three ways plants interact with incoming light?

options.label: A
options.text: Converting light into chemical energy

options.label: B
options.text: Radiating light back out at a different wavelength

options.label: C
options.text: Absorbing more light than they're able to consume

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: A farmer notices that the plants in their cropland are experiencing stress. What measure can be used to infer the health of these plants, rather than relying on visible signs of stress?

options.label: A
options.text: Levels of greenness

options.label: B
options.text: Chlorophyll fluorescence

options.label: C
options.text: Photosynthetic activity

options.label: D
options.text: Levels of carbon dioxide

multiple-choice.question: What is a benefit of tracking chlorophyll fluorescence from space?

options.label: A
options.text: Monitoring the effects of drought in the Amazon and Great Plains

options.label: B
options.text: Gauging the health of ecosystems worldwide

options.label: C
options.text: Estimating the amount of oxygen released by plants

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: How does the amount of light absorbed by plants relate to their ability to photosynthesize?

options.label: A
options.text: Plants that absorb more light are able to photosynthesize more efficiently

options.label: B
options.text: Plants that absorb less light are able to photosynthesize more efficiently

options.label: C
options.text: Plants that absorb more light are able to photosynthesize at a slower rate

options.label: D
options.text: Plants that absorb more light at a rate that is not related to their photosynthetic activity

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary benefit of using chlorophyll fluorescence as a measure of plant health, compared to relying on visible signs of stress?

options.label: A
options.text: It can detect stress earlier than visible signs

options.label: B
options.text: It is a more direct measure of photosynthetic activity

options.label: C
options.text: It is less expensive than other methods

options.label: D
options.text: It is more reliable than other methods

multiple-choice.question: What is a byproduct of photosynthesis?

options.label: A
options.text: Oxygen

options.label: B
options.text: Carbon dioxide

options.label: C
options.text: Glucose

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: How does the process of chlorophyll fluorescence relate to the process of photosynthesis?

options.label: A
options.text: Chlorophyll fluorescence occurs before photosynthesis

options.label: B
options.text: Chlorophyll fluorescence occurs during photosynthesis

options.label: C
options.text: Chlorophyll fluorescence occurs after photosynthesis

options.label: D
options.text: Chlorophyll fluorescence is a separate process from photosynthesis

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of tracking chlorophyll fluorescence from space?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows us to monitor the health of ecosystems worldwide

options.label: B
options.text: It allows us to estimate the amount of oxygen released by plants

options.label: C
options.text: It allows us to track the effects of drought in the Amazon and Great Plains

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: How does the discovery of chlorophyll fluorescence relate to our understanding of the Earth's ecosystems?

options.label: A
options.text: It has no relation to our understanding of the Earth's ecosystems

options.label: B
options.text: It has a minor relation to our understanding of the Earth's ecosystems

options.label: C
options.text: It has a significant relation to our understanding of the Earth's ecosystems

options.label: D
options.text: It has a crucial relation to our understanding of the Earth's ecosystems

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why plants regularly absorb more light than they're able to consume?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase their photosynthetic activity

options.label: B
options.text: To protect themselves from excessive light

options.label: C
options.text: To store energy for later use

options.label: D
options.text: To dissipate excess light as heat

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Earth's red glow observed by satellite?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a sign of plant stress

options.label: B
options.text: It is a sign of plant health

options.label: C
options.text: It is a sign of the Earth's temperature

options.label: D
options.text: It is a sign of chlorophyll fluorescence
